1496984451527876608.text: The U.S. and our increasingly tight-knit European allies made every effort to use diplomacy to avert war and bloodshed. Now we will make sure that Putin, and other authoritarian leaders everywhere, know that invasion of another’s sovereignty comes with steep costs.

1496984318433914883.text: The shift in Ukrainian attitude away from Russia and toward the West, even in Russian-speaking areas near the Russian border, poses a threat to Putin’s personal power and ego.

1482035914977296386.text: I believe it will be the most important week of my Senate career.

1482035874934276103.text: And we’ll grapple with a fundamental question—what is more important, acting to protect our democracy or adhering to outdated Senate rules that have often been changed over time by both parties?

1482035600333197316.text: I will discuss how Virginians in the 1950’s and 60’s holding the seat I now occupy used the filibuster to push Massive Resistance to civil rights laws.

1482035564144742401.text: And we’ll discuss Senate rules, including the filibuster and its sad history of being used to block civil rights laws.

1482035504359038977.text: We’ll discuss how our laws will require minimum standards for voting in federal elections, non-partisan redistricting in Congressional races, transparency of all campaign contributions.

1482035410985439236.text: We will dig into the coordinated assault on voting—the attack of January 6 and efforts in many states to restrict voting and undermine electoral integrity.

1482035345524994049.text: We are scrapping our traditional MLK recess to have this debate. So appropriate.

1482035209906368512.text: Up until now, Republicans have blocked our ability to even consider voting rights—essentially a “gag rule” on this topic. But we have found a path to begin debate on the Freedom to Vote Act and John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act even over Republican opposition.

1482035085738225668.text: Beginning Tuesday, the Senate will proceed to consider voting rights legislation for the first time in my Senate career.

1481696690587512837.text: Just like we responded to violence against John Lewis on Bloody Sunday and disenfranchisement with the Voting Rights Act, we need to respond to the violent attack on January 6 and disenfranchisement efforts across the country with the #FTVA and #JLVRAA.

1481420539633745923.text: It was an honor to meet with @OfficialMLK3 and Arndrea Waters King. We are all agreed: It’s time to reform Senate rules and pass comprehensive voting rights legislation. https://t.co/vqfVi9n0xs

1438940668731199489.text: When Dr. Lorna Breen, a Charlottesville native and frontline ER physician, died by suicide in April 2020, her family took their unimaginable grief and channeled it into the cause of making sure our health care professionals can come forward and ask for mental health support.

1438940666684395520.text: Today is National Physician Suicide Awareness Day. Now more than ever before, it is so deeply important to acknowledge the incredible burdens placed on health care professionals and the profound trauma wrought by this ongoing pandemic.

1437777507219124227.text: We have said for months that we won't give up on this issue because it lies at the very heart of our American values. I'm proud to have worked with many of my colleagues on this critical legislation—now let's go get it passed.

1437777505876905992.text: This legislation includes commonsense measures like automatic and online voter registration, uniform early voting, a public holiday for Election Day, and improving vote by mail access. It also works to promote election integrity and prevent interference and partisan subversion.

1437777504668987400.text: I was a civil rights lawyer for 17 years, lived through a violent attack on the Capitol by people wanting to overturn an election, and am watching state legislatures scheme to reduce the ability to vote. The right to vote is the cornerstone of our democracy—we must protect it.

1437777503419047941.text: Today I'm joining my colleagues to introduce the Freedom to Vote Act—legislation that will ensure eligible voters across the country get access to the ballot. We must protect the right to vote and strengthen our democracy, and this is a critical step forward in that fight.

1436703773037113345.text: And it's why I've been steadfast in opposing wars initiated without congressional debate and approval—the consequences are so great that initiation and maintenance of war must be done with care and close oversight. If the last 20 years have taught us anything, it should be that.

1436703771308986377.text: In my work as a member of the Armed Services Committee, I think about that sacrifice every day. It’s why I'm so committed to ensuring our troops have the resources to defend our nation and that our veterans and military families have the support and benefits we promised them.

1436703769769750536.text: The 20th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks is a somber and emotional occasion, particularly in Virginia. Our Commonwealth suffered directly that day, and thousands of Virginians have served and sacrificed in the 20 years of war since then.

1436666165984702472.text: Today I join my fellow Americans in remembering the nearly 3,000 lives that were cut short on 9/11, honoring the first responders who risked their lives to save others, and extending my deepest appreciation to all who have served our nation with honor since that tragic day.

1435969655290548226.text: Amy Klobuchar is one of my best friends in the Senate. She works hard with her head up and a smile on her face. Anne and I are thinking of Amy and her family today and are so glad she is doing well. https://t.co/Mf10su8Gvy

1407756581836673024.text: And so, surrounded by his friends and family, I address John Warner as he used to address me—“Well old friend, today you are at home.”

1407756580246867972.text: But today I celebrate John's impact over a three decade tenure in the Senate. The family he created from Senate colleagues—not just Senators, but committee staff, Capitol Police, food service workers, Senate gym employees. The ever-present curiosity and twinkle in the eye he had.

1407756578137255937.text: John Warner saw the Capitol under attack on January 6. He was deeply saddened by the assault on our democracy. We all should be. Today I am forced to wonder, will we step up to defend our nation as John did?

1407756276214419459.text: John joined the Navy as soon as he graduated from high school during World War II, and then rejoined the Marine Corps when the U.S. entered the Korean War. He did this at risk to his life, health, and career. But of course he prioritized defending the nation above all else.

1407756275484696585.text: As I entered public life, what impressed me most about John was his obvious belief that country and character count above all else. He was a Republican and I am a Democrat—but that never mattered. He never hesitated to prioritize his country over the orthodoxy of the day.

1407756274289233925.text: Long before I knew John Warner the patriotic public servant, I was honored to consider John a friend. It was only upon coming to the Senate—four years after he retired—that I came to fully understand the mark he left on the Senate, his beloved Commonwealth, and his country.

1407756272745787397.text: Today I was deeply honored to be able to share some of my thoughts at my dear friend John Warner's funeral—and I'd like to share some of them here as well, in memory of a man who truly exemplified love of country and character:

1407708631727026183.text: There must be a thorough review of all Tier 1 Group contracts and stronger State Department oversight of U.S. defense services provided to foreign nations—especially ones with problematic human rights records like Saudi Arabia, to ensure something like this never happens again.

1407708630745600004.text: These reports confirm what I feared to be true when I pressed Trump’s DOD nominee and Tier 1 board member Louis Bremer on this disturbing subject last year: Saudi nationals responsible for assassinating Mr. Khashoggi were trained by Tier 1 Group, a U.S. private security company. https://t.co/0lK69o3Ocv

1407467933421522945.text: So what's next? We have to pass voting rights. I'm going to do everything I can, and we might need to get creative—but we are not accepting failure on this existential issue. The burden is on Democrats' shoulders now, and we're going to move forward and find solutions.

1407467560153518082.text: Republicans have filibustered the January 6th commission. Equal pay. Now voting rights. On ALL these policies that matter to the American people, they are determined to block us. But we're the majority—and we need to act like it.

1407465280595501057.text: If Republicans won’t protect our democracy—after an attack on the Capitol, after state legislatures blatantly try to take voting rights away from Americans—Democrats have to. Period. https://t.co/19oLbZR1fx

1405338680227680259.text: It is my hope that we will get a comprehensive voting rights bill—with all 50 Democrats on board—on the Senate floor for a vote in the coming weeks.

1405338679074344963.text: While states like Virginia are making incredible progress on protecting voting rights, Congress has a significant role to play—as we did in the 1960s with the VRA—in stopping states from interfering with people’s ability to choose their leaders.

1405338677828587527.text: It is absolutely imperative—and made even more dramatically so by the attack on our democracy on January 6—that we protect the voting rights of the American people. My thoughts right now:

1374479350012153858.text: Just as the families affected by these horrible gun violence tragedies come from all political parties, so must the leaders who work to prevent them. We don’t have to accept this. We can change it. But we've got to put the safety of the American public over our politics—and soon.

1374479348888076288.text: Why haven't we been able to pass reforms like this before? Preventing gun violence sadly has been a partisan issue, and it's been difficult to get Republican votes. But these are not crimes that respect anybody’s politics—the victims are from red states and blue states alike.

1374479347826847746.text: It includes measures to make background checks universal, prevent access by minors, limit handgun purchases, promote responsible gun ownership, safeguard victims of domestic violence, and more. These are commonsense reforms that we know can make a difference.

1374479346732204035.text: After the Virginia legislature took steps to combat the scourge of gun violence in 2020, @MarkWarner and I introduced the Virginia Plan to Reduce Gun Violence Act in the Senate, which was modeled after the slate of measures Virginia adopted.

1374479345524215816.text: No single bill is going to prevent every single gun tragedy—but we know we can reduce crimes like this with measures like comprehensive background checks. It’s imperative that leaders in Washington take meaningful action to keep the American public safe.

1374479344454692864.text: The tragedies in Atlanta last week and Boulder yesterday—two of seven mass shootings that happened in the U.S. in a seven-day span—of course make us ask: Will we finally act to reduce gun violence in the United States? Here are some of my thoughts:

1374384118100758538.text:
11 years after it was signed into law by @BarackObama, the Affordable Care Act continues to save lives. 

Health care is a human right, and through continuing to protect and build upon the ACA, we've got to reach universal coverage and make sure no one is left behind.

1374354810091212800.text: My heart breaks for the families who are mourning in Boulder. For the lives taken too soon. It breaks for the seven children left behind by Officer Eric Talley. And it breaks for our country as we reckon with more senseless gun violence. Enough is enough.

1374055668043419651.text:
Virginia’s neighbors in D.C. deserve representation just like every other American.

1367539369997979648.text: The Dr. Lorna Breen Health Care Provider Protection Act is just one piece of the work we need to do to support our frontline workers throughout this pandemic—but it's an absolutely critical piece. 1367539366898380805.text:
In April 2020 Dr. Lorna Breen, a physician from Charlottesville, Virginia, working on the frontlines of the pandemic in New York, died by suicide—bringing this issue to the forefront of our national attention.

The issue of keeping our healers healthy cannot be ignored.

1367539366072098819.text:
Today I'm reintroducing the Dr. Lorna Breen Health Care Provider Protection Act—legislation to reduce and prevent suicide, burnout, and mental health conditions among health care professionals.

I will vote to convict because seven people needlessly died and hundreds were injured by a former President’s egregious lies.

1360690215719960579.text: And make no mistake: The events of January 6th—seven dead, the first siege of our Capitol in over 200 years, the disruption of the peaceful transfer of power—are the direct result of that first acquittal.

1360690214189076490.text:
I will vote to convict President Trump in his second impeachment trial.
 
A year ago—upon the conclusion of President Trump’s first impeachment trial—I said “Unchallenged evil spreads like a virus,” and that an acquittal would lead to worse behavior.

1360605570814861313.text: Question for my Senate colleagues: Rioters shouted “hang Mike Pence” and called him a traitor. Where did they get the idea that Pence did anything wrong?

1360573968273522689.text: Trump saw Congress under siege as an opportunity to stop the peaceful transfer of power! And hours later, when Capitol police were still fighting for their lives, he had Giuliani call Tuberville to beg again.

1360573967493443587.text: Most shocking revelation from trial thus far: Pence taken from chamber to protect his life at 2:13 pm. Trump sends tweet trashing Pence to millions, then calls Tuberville while Senate is under lockdown. He asks Tuberville for help to delay—or stop—calling the election.

The Cabinet should invoke the 25th Amendment against Trump. If he wants to challenge, Congress should vote him out.

1347177479249793026.text: What took 34 minutes in 2017 took more than 14 hours in 2021—because, goaded by the President and abetted by some of my fellow Senators, right-wing insurrectionists stormed the Capitol in support of an effort to overturn the election results and install an unelected government. https://t.co/ydXA6zD3Wh

1347173995855171586.text: In today's very early hours, we certified the Electoral College results, making official what we have known since November: that at noon on January 20th, President-elect Biden and Vice President-elect Harris will lead our nation to a healthier, fairer, more prosperous future. https://t.co/xQwSWqNjW5

1347005827325030406.text: But more importantly—as the body that acted together to guarantee Americans the right to vote—if we object, we will become the agent of one of the most massive disenfranchisements in the history of this country. The United States Senate cannot and must not allow that to happen.

1347005826486177794.text: If we object to these electoral results, we’re saying to states: No matter how safe and secure your elections are, we’ll gladly overturn them if we don't like the results.

1347005825630556161.text:
After John Lewis was savagely beaten on Bloody Sunday, the US Senate came together to pass the Voting Rights Act.

We should be coming together today—after more violence—to affirm the votes cast in November. Instead we’re contemplating an unprecedented act of disenfranchisement.

1347005824800075782.text: Tonight I spoke on the Senate floor about exactly what objecting to these electoral results means for our country:

1346962929984430080.text: Not since the Burning of Washington by the British during the War of 1812 has the Capitol been attacked. The violence we saw today was an anti-American, anti-democratic assault on our nation. All must condemn it in the strongest of terms.

1346935400267452429.text: My staff and I are safe right now—following the instructions of Capitol Police and praying for the safety of Capitol workers, members of the press, and all here in Washington today. This violence must end now.

1346869888271470592.text:
To any of my Senate colleagues looking to overturn state electoral results and undermine our democracy today: I hope you’ll take a look in the mirror and consider how you want to be remembered in our history books.

Don’t sell your soul to join a toddler in his tantrum.

1346865667648188418.text: The American public is telling us loud and clear that we need bold action to get out of the disaster that was 2020. 1222624508068225025.text: I've had trials in the Richmond traffic court, and I had cases in the U.S. Supreme Court. I had trials that lasted an hour, and I had trials that lasted weeks. Not once in 17 years did I ever have a trial where there were not witnesses or documents. Not once.

1221849288025632768.text: Today we commemorate the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz. We commit to always remember the horrors of the Holocaust to help prevent future atrocities, and we vow to combat anti-Semitism and hate in all its forms. #HolocaustRemembranceDay

1221138766028582919.text:
Trump’s lawyers said cross-examination of witnesses is “the greatest legal engine ever invented for the discovery of truth.”

If that’s true, why would they push forward with a trial without witnesses and documents? Are they afraid we will discover the truth?

1220893527036448768.text: But more importantly, it suggests to me that they are afraid of what is in those documents. And they are afraid of what the witnesses will say in testimony. And that should tell the American public something.

1220893524222070784.text: The fact that the White House was so adamant against producing any documents and that the Republican majority has so far stood against the presentation of the full evidentiary record suggests that it’s not really a fair trial.

1220893522192003073.text: We’re either interested in finding the facts or we’re not; we’re either interested in the truth or we’re not. I do not believe that an impeachment trial should operate at a lesser standard than a trial in a traffic court in the city of Richmond—but that's where we are right now.

1220893520770134016.text: I’ve taken an oath to do impartial justice and I’m going to keep an open mind until the proceedings are done. But I'm disappointed that my colleagues have yet to embrace what anyone who’s been in any courtroom understands: you can’t have a trial without witnesses and documents.

1220893518727565312.text:
As jurors we're grappling with 3 questions:

1. What are the facts?
2. Do the facts establish either or both of the articles of impeachment?
3. If they do, did they establish them at such a level—a high crime or misdemeanor—to warrant removal of the President from office?

964202162287980550.text: The past few weeks, we’ve tried every approach to getting permanent protection for Dreamers. It’s been my primary focus in the immigration negotiations. I firmly believe the bipartisan deal today is our best chance to pass a bill to shield them from deportation.
